Visit 1: Graphing Lines

Math 100L Lesson 11 PDF

Bring your math textbook to Visit #1 and Visit #2.

Speaking Skill: Questions

Read the following information to your Speaking Partner:

As a student, one of the most important things you do is to ask questions. By asking questions, you are able to gain understanding of the new material. There are several ways to ask questions in English. Let’s review the important question words.

Question Word

Usage

Example

What

To ask about the nature of things and substances

What time is it?

Where

To ask about a location

Where do I draw this line?

Who

To ask about identity

Who is he?

Whose

To ask about possession

Whose pen is this?

Why

To ask about reason and purpose

Why do I make this number negative?

Which

To ask about a set of choices

Which numbers can go here?

How

To ask about process and method

How do I graph this line?

After asking questions, it is important that you ask follow-up questions. This helps you make sure you understand the material. Use phrases such as:

I think I understand this. Is this the right way?
It seems pretty clear. Did I do it correctly?
Can you tell me if I got this right?
I wonder if you could do that for me one more time.
Is there another way to solve this problem?
Could you show me how to do it?

Discussion Questions

  • Do you feel that you know the question words?
  • What does it mean to ask follow-up questions?
  • Are you comfortable asking your instructor questions on the Internet?
  • Is it a good idea to write down questions and practice them before speaking online?
  • Play “20 Questions” with your Speaking Partner. Have your speaking partner explain how to play the game. Have your Speaking Partner think of a career. You ask questions to find out what career he/she has chosen. Then you think of a career and have your Speaking Partner ask you questions.

Graphing Lines

This week you will learn how to graph the solutions to equations. Read the following information to your Speaking Partner:

This equation has two variables: 3x + 2y = 5. In this type of equation, there is an “x” and a “y” to solve. The solution to this equation will not be a single number, but a pair of numbers. The answers will look something like this: (3, -2). There are several solutions to this problem such as (1, 1) (-1, 4) (5, -5). If we pick a number for x and put it in the equation, then we will be able to solve for y. The solutions to these equations are pairs of numbers that we can put on a graph.



You will notice that all of the solutions are in a straight line. If we connect them, we get all of the solutions for the equation. It is important to realize that if we draw the line that connects the dots, all of the points on that line are solutions. The correct answer to the math problem: “graph the line 3x +2y = 5” is the graph above.

You can fill out a table to help you graph an equation. If your equation is y = (1/4)x - 2, then the table might look like this:

xy
4 -1
0 -2
8 0
20 3

Notice that we really only need two points to get the pattern. It is often easy to select 0 for x, and then 0 for y.

Do the following exercises with your Speaking Partner.

Fill out a table for each of the following equations:

a. x + y = 8

b. 4x + 3y = 9

Solve the following equations and then graph the lines.

a. 3x + y = 10

b. 5x + 2y = 6

Visit 2: Finding Slope

Bring your math textbook to Speaking Partner visit #2.

This week you are learning how to find the slope between two points. Read the following information to your Speaking Partner:

The slope of the line between two points is found by taking how much it changes up and down over how much it changes left and right. The symbol for slope is the letter m. The following are some properties of slopes: 1) bigger numbers for slope correspond to steeper lines; 2) positive slopes head up as you go to the right; and 3) negative slopes will head down as you go to the right. The formula for finding slopes is:

m = (y2-y1)/(x2-x1)

Discussion Questions

  1. Do you understand how to find the slope between pairs of points?
  2. Why does Brother Baird bring up the subject of roads in this chapter?

Solve the following problems with your Speaking Partner:

  1. Find the slope between each pair of points:
    1. (4, -2) (7, 3)
    2. (-6, 1) (-5, 5)
    3. (4, 8) (-5, 6)
  2. Find two points of each line and then use those points to find the slope:
    1. 2x - 3y = 1
    2. 5x - y = 10
    3. 2x + 7y = 1

Pronunciation Practice

English pronunciation of the -s ending

The “s” ending has three pronunciations. The pronunciation depends on the last sound of the word. The “s” endings are found at the end of verbs, plural nouns, and possessive nouns.

  • It is pronounced as “iz” after -ch, -sh, -s, and -z endings.
    teaches, brushes, buses, boxes, buzzes
  • It is pronounced as “s” after -k, -f, -p, or -t endings.
    breaks, cliffs, stops, charts
  • It is pronounced as “z” after voiced endings
    dogs, mothers, serves, approves, heads

Listen to your Speaking Partner say the following words with an “s” ending. Then repeat the words. What is the ending sound of each of the words?

reads

judges

divides

risks

assumes

estimates

borrows

identifies

occurs

invests

Listen to your Speaking Partner say the following nouns with a plural ending. Then repeat the words. What is the ending sound of each of the words?

variables

buses

inches

cities

girls

thieves

photos

kisses

hearts

fifths

Listen to your Speaking Partner say the following possessive nouns. Then repeat the words.

the student’s

Linda’s

Brother Baird’s

the teacher’s

Do the following activities with your Speaking Partner:

1. Choose three words from those listed above. Ask your speaking partner a question using those three words. Do this back and forth so that you have each asked and answered five questions.

2. Practice your pronunciation by repeating the following phrases several times:

He owes his sisters lots of favors because they always wash his clothes.
The judges’ watches were different colors but the faces were white.
She sells seashells down by the sea’s shore.
